{{BLP sources|date=February 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Gamal Mubarak
Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù | image = Gamal Mubarak.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|12|27}} | birth_place = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | nationality =[[Egypt]]ian, [[United Kingdom|British]] {{cite web|author=AlJazeeraEnglish |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iKWGOXMnTRk |title=âªWhere in the world is Gamal Mubarak?â¬â |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-06-05}} | party = [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] | alma_mater =[[American University in Cairo]] }} '''Gamal Al Din Mohammed Hosni Sayed Mubarak''' ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙ ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø³ÙÙ Ø³ÙØ¯ ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù}}, {{IPA-arz|É¡Ã¦ËmÃ¦Ël edËdiËn mÃ¦ËÄ§Ã¦mmÃ¦d ËÄ§osni ËsÃ¦jjed moËbÉËÉ¾Ë¤Ék|IPA}}), (born on December 27, 1963), is the younger of the two sons of ousted [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] and former First Lady [[Suzanne Mubarak]]. In contrast to his older brother [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], Gamal had pursued an active public profile and was starting to wield some influence on political life in the country before the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution|revolution]] of early 2011. Prior to the revolution, Gamal was the deputy secretary-general of the then-ruling and now-dissolved [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]], and head of its influential policies committee. For his early education, he attended [[St. George's College, Cairo]] before entering the [[American University in Cairo]]. He graduated with a [[Business]] Degree from the university and he claims he also earned an [[MBA]] from the school.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} He began his professional life working for [[Bank of America]]. He worked primarily in the field of [[investment banking]]. With a few colleagues, Mubarak left Bank of America to set up London-based [[Medinvest Associates Ltd]], which manages a [[private equity fund]], and to do some corporate finance consultancy work.{{cite web|url=http://www.winne.com/topinterviews/gamal.htm |title=Interview with MR. GAMAL MUBARAK Hairman Of Medinvest Associates Ltd |publisher=Winne.com |date=1999-01-14 |accessdate=2011-06-05}} His role with Medinvest has since ended.''' Mubarak is also the former [[Chairman]] of the Future Generation Foundation (FGF), an NGO dedicated to job training, and a former honorary member of the [[Rotary International|Rotary]], which was awarded to him in May 2000 by then Rotary International president Frank Devlyn.[http://www.frankdevlyn.org/galleries/Egypt/egypt6.jpg ]{{dead link|date=June 2011}} In May 2007, Mubarak married Khadija El Gammal, the daughter of Egyptian businessman Mahmoud El Gammal. They have a daughter, Farida, who was born in 2010. During the first week of the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]] there were unconfirmed reports and speculation that Gamal may have left Egypt during the protests. However, on February 3, 2011, Gamal was present for an ABC News interview of his father in Cairo.[http://abcnews.go.com/International/egypt-abc-news-christiane-amanpour-exclusive-interview-president/story?id=12833673&page=3 Feb. 3 interview with Christine Amanpour] On 13 April 2011, Gamal was imprisoned for 15 days pending investigations for corruption, abuse of power, and for his alleged role in causing the fatalities and casualties of peaceful protesters during the revolution which was sparked on January 25, 2011. == Inheritance of Power == The grooming of Gamal Mubarak to be his father's successor as the next president of Egypt became increasingly evident at around the year 2000.Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73–88 With no vice-president, and with no heir-apparent in sight, Gamal started enjoying considerable attention in Egyptian state-run media.Brownlee, Jason (2008) [https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf "The Heir Apparency of Gamal Mubarak"] ''Arab Studies Journal'' pp. 36–56 [[Bashar al-Asad]]'s rise to power in [[Syria]] in June 2000 just hours after [[Hafez al-Asad]]'s death, sparked a heated debate in the Egyptian press regarding the prospects for a similar scenario occurring in Cairo.Sobelman, Daniel (2001) [http://www.meforum.org/27/gamal-mubarak-president-of-egypt "Gamal Mubarak, President of Egypt?"] ''Middle East Quarterly'' 8(2): pp. 31–40 Both President Mubarak and his son denied the possibility of any inheritance of power in Egypt. More recently, this claim was made in early 2006, when Gamal Mubarak declared repeatedly that he had no aspiration to succeed his father, but that he would maintain his position in the then-ruling NDP as deputy secretary general, a post he held in addition to heading the party's policy committee, allegedly the most important organ of the NDP.[http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096 http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096]{{dl|date=November 2010}} In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm]{{dl|date=November 2010}} On February 26, 2005, Mubarak ordered the constitution changed to allow multi-candidate presidential elections before September 2005 by asking parliament to amend Article 76 of the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]]. This change in the constitution was seen then by some analysts and senior judicial figures as a ploy to seamlessly allow Gamal Mubarak to inherit the top position in Egypt. According to this view, Gamal Mubarak would be one of the candidates in a presidential elections and would be supported by the ruling party and the government-controlled media. Since remaining serious candidates would be disqualified by the NDP-controlled [[People's Assembly]] leaving only the less popular candidates, the inheritance of power would be accomplished through a "democratic" process. Following the commencement of the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]], [[Omar Suleiman]] was appointed the vice-president of Egypt on January 29, 2011.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/uk-egypt-suleiman-idUKTRE70S2JL20110129 Omar Suleiman, new Egyptian vice-president] Suleiman announced on 3 February 2011 that Gamal Mubarak would not seek election. == Role in the ouster of his father, Hosni Mubarak == Some political analysts{{cite web|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/02/13/108650/egypt-insider-mubaraks-fall-was.html |title=Egypt insider: Mubarak's fall was years in the making | McClatchy |publisher=Mcclatchydc.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-05}} speculate that the alleged deteriorating state of the Egyptian economy in the last days of [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s rule was caused by Gamal and his friends taking over as a political advisers to Mubarak. On the other hand, a wide range of analysts credit Gamal Mubarak for reviving the Egyptian economy over the past five years, from a stagnant, mostly state-run economy to a largely free market system that enjoyed 5% GDP growth. [[Reuters]] Africa reports of a fight taking place between him and his older brother, [[Alaa Mubarak]]. Alaa supposedly accused him of ruining his father's last days, and humiliating him.{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71C0HQ20110213 |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows-paper | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=2011-02-13 |accessdate=2011-06-05}} == Allegations of corruption == Following the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, media sources started to point to the financial dealings of Gamal Mubarak, which were described as suspicious. On 28 February 2011 the Egyptian daily [[Al-Ahram]] published a list of bank accounts allegedly belonging to Gamal Mubarak. Al-Ahram reported that the Chief Prosecutor of Egypt received a report that Gamal Mubarak inexplicably amassed significant sums of money that were deposited in these accounts. This allegation came on background of a decision from the Prosecutor General of Egypt to freeze all bank accounts belonging to the Mubarak family, including Gamal Mubarak.{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/457/2011/02/28/25/64884.aspx |title=Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø³Ø±ÙØ© ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¦ÙØ© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¨ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© 147ÙÙÙÙÙ Ø¯ÙÙØ§Ø± ÙØ³ÙØ²Ø§Ù Ù200 ÙÙÙÙÙ ÙØ¹ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ù |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-05}} The Egyptian Appeals Court ordered that Mubarak's financial status is reviewed by the court on March 5, 2011. It is expected that the court will render a decision in that hearing whether or not to uphold the decision to freeze Mubarak's assets.{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/february/28/37187 |title=5ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ Ø£ÙÙÙ Ø¬ÙØ³Ø§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ¸Ø± ÙÙ ØªØ¬ÙÙØ¯ Ø£Ø±ØµØ¯Ø© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù..Ù26ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø±Ø´ÙØ¯ ÙØ¹Ø² ÙØ¹Ø³Ù | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-06-05}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * Interview with Gamal Mubarak: "[http://www.meforum.org/article/2063 We Need Audacious Leaders]", ''Middle East Quarterly'', Winter 2009 * Egypt: Time of the Reformers, Interview by [[Pascal Drouhaud]], ''[[Politique internationale]]'', nÂ° 120, Paris, 2008 * Daniel Sobelman, "[http://www.meforum.org/article/27 Gamal Mubarak: President of Egypt?]", ''Middle East Quarterly'', Spring 2001 * [http://ndp.org.eg/ National Democratic Party] * [http://web.amnesty.org/report2005/egy-summary-eng Amnesty International's 2005 Report on Egypt] * [[BBC News Online|BBC]]: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3646026.stm "Mubarak son raises public profile"], September 10, 2004. * [[MSNBC]]: [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/5529166/ "Stage set for political dynasty in Egypt?"], July 28, 2004. *[[Foreign Policy]]: {{cite web|url=http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/09/20/is_gamal_mubarak_the_best_hope_for_egyptian_democracy_0 |title=Is Gamal Mubarak the Best Hope for Egyptian Democracy? | The Middle East Channel |publisher=Mideast.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-05}} *[http://www.memritv.org/Transcript.asp?P1=1274 Egypt Has a Right to Nuclear Energy for Peaceful Purposes. Nuclear Energy - a Possible Alternative in the Future] 9/20/2006 {{Persondata | NAME = Mubarak, Gamal | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | Email = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 27 December 1963 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mubarak, Gamal}} {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Egyptian Muslims]] [[Category:Egyptian people of Welsh descent]] [[Category:American University in Cairo alumni]] [[Category:National Democratic Party (Egypt) politicians]] [[Category:People of the 2011 Egyptian revolution]] [[Category:St. George's College, Cairo alumni]] [[ar:Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù]] [[az:Camal MÃ¼barÉk]] [[da:Gamal Mubarak]] [[de:Gamal Mubarak]] [[eo:Gamal Mubarak]] [[fr:Gamal Moubarak]] [[ko:ê°ë§ ë¬´ë°ë¼í¬]] [[it:Gamal Mubarak]] [[he:×××× ×××××¨×]] [[arz:Ø¬ÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù]] [[pl:Gamal Mubarak]] [[ru:ÐÑÐ±Ð°ÑÐ°Ðº, ÐÐ°Ð¼Ð°Ð»Ñ]] [[tr:Cemal MÃ¼barek]] [[uk:ÒÐ°Ð¼Ð°Ð»Ñ ÐÑÐ±Ð°ÑÐ°Ðº]]
